DOC.HEAD: Daiwa Securities Acknowledges Unfair Stock Transactions
DOC.TEXT: Daiwa Securities Co. has been punished for compensating a customer for losses in stock transactions, a company official said Tuesday. The official said the company had not violated any laws, but quoted Daiwa President Masahiro Dozen as apologizing for unfairness to other investors. The Finance Ministry has prohibited Daiwa, one of four major Japanese securities firms, from raising capital through public share offerings for the time being, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The ministry also ordered the company to refrain from corporate customer business for two days, he added. Finance Ministry officials were not available for comment after office hours Tuesday. Kyodo News Service said the ministry had discovered that Daiwa Securities compensated for a corporate customer's losses in stock transactions between 1975 and 1980, but could not find out whether Daiwa had entered into a contract guaranteeing the customer against losses in stock transactions, a violation of the Securities and Exchange Law. Kyodo said the ministry's investigation showed Daiwa had obtained about 12 billion yen, or $84 million, from selling a subsidiary's stock and paid 11.3 billion yen to a customer that had lost in stock transactions and 700 million yen as a commission to a company that settled the matter. The Daiwa official confirmed such transactions, but declined to give figures. He said four former Daiwa employees involved in the affair would resign. The pay of Dozen and 11 other executives would be cut by 10 percent for periods of three months to one year, the official said. Kyodo said the ministry investigated after press reports alleged that Daiwa had filed false business reports to cover up losses it incurred in compensating the customer.
